questions.question: What are unguided transmission media?

options.text: Unguided media transport electromagnetic waves without a physical conductor; they are commonly called wireless communication.
Unguided media transport electromagnetic waves without using a physical conductor; they are commonly referred to as wireless communication.
Unguided media transport signals only through copper conductors and require shielding to reduce interference.
Unguided media are guided channels where signals stay inside a cable like twisted pair or fiber.

questions.explanation: Unguided media carry electromagnetic waves through air (or space) without a physical conductor, which is why they are often called wireless communication.

questions.question: How are signals transmitted in unguided media?

options.text: Signals are sent as light pulses confined in a glass core by total internal reflection.
Signals are broadcast through air and can be received by any device capable of receiving them.
Signals are carried only inside a cable and protected from being received outside the conduit.
Signals must be forwarded hop-by-hop by switches using MAC addresses on a wired segment.

questions.explanation: In unguided transmission, signals are typically broadcast through air, so they can be received by devices that can detect the same frequency/band.

questions.question: What are the main ways unguided signals travel from source to destination?

options.text: Ground propagation, sky propagation, and line-of-sight propagation.
Baseband, broadband, and multiplexed propagation.
Step-index, graded-index, and single-mode propagation.
Simplex, half-duplex, and full-duplex propagation.

questions.explanation: The lesson explains three unguided propagation methods: ground propagation, sky propagation, and line-of-sight propagation.

questions.question: What is ground propagation?

options.text: Radio waves travel through the lowest portion of the atmosphere, hugging the earth and following its curvature.
Very high-frequency signals travel in straight lines directly from antenna to antenna.
Higher-frequency radio waves radiate into the ionosphere and are reflected back to earth.
Radio waves travel through the lowest portion of the atmosphere, hugging the earth and following its curvature.

questions.explanation: Ground propagation sends radio waves close to the earth’s surface; the waves spread outward and follow the curvature of the planet.

questions.question: What frequency range is used in ground propagation?

options.text: Carrier frequencies up to 2 MHz.
Carrier frequencies between 30 MHz and 85 MHz.
Carrier frequencies up to 2 MHz.
Carrier frequencies between 1 GHz and 300 GHz.

questions.explanation: Ground waves are low-frequency signals; the course specifies carrier frequencies up to 2 MHz for ground propagation.

questions.question: What is an example of ground propagation?

options.text: AM radio.
Microwave links between towers.
Infrared remote-control communication.
AM radio.

questions.explanation: The lesson uses AM radio as the example of ground wave propagation.

questions.question: What type of coverage does ground propagation provide?

options.text: Relatively local radio communication coverage, suitable for a particular locality.
Global coverage independent of earth curvature, with no range limitation.
Only indoor short-range coverage because signals cannot travel outdoors.
Only line-of-sight coverage limited to about 100 km for ground stations.

questions.explanation: Ground propagation provides relatively local radio coverage, often used by broadcast stations targeting a specific area.

questions.question: What is sky propagation?

options.text: Very high-frequency signals are transmitted in straight lines directly from antenna to antenna.
Higher-frequency radio waves radiate upward into the ionosphere and are reflected back to earth.
Radio waves travel along the ground, hugging the earth and following its curvature.
Signals are transmitted only inside coaxial cables to reduce interference.

questions.explanation: Sky propagation sends radio waves up to the ionosphere, where they are reflected back down, enabling long-distance transmission.

questions.question: What is the frequency range of sky propagation?

options.text: Up to 2 MHz.
30 MHz to 85 MHz.
1 GHz to 300 GHz.
30 MHz to 85 MHz.

questions.explanation: The lesson states sky propagation operates in the 30–85 MHz range.

questions.question: What factors affect sky propagation?

options.text: Weather conditions, time of day, and the state of the ionosphere.
Only the cable type and connector quality.
Only the MAC address of the receiver.
Only the distance between two aligned towers in direct view.

questions.explanation: Because sky propagation depends on the ionosphere, it varies with conditions such as weather and time of day.

questions.question: What is the advantage of sky propagation?

options.text: Allows long-distance transmission with lower power output.
Eliminates the need for antennas because signals stay inside a conductor.
Allows long-distance transmission with lower power output.
Guarantees that signals are confined to a private medium so they cannot be intercepted.

questions.explanation: Sky propagation enables longer distances even with lower power, because the ionosphere reflects signals back toward the earth.

questions.question: What is line-of-sight propagation?

options.text: Very high-frequency signals travel in straight lines directly from antenna to antenna.
Low-frequency signals spread along the ground and follow the planet’s curvature.
Higher-frequency waves bounce off the ionosphere and return to earth.
Signals are guided through a copper conductor with foil and braid shielding.

questions.explanation: Line-of-sight propagation uses very high frequencies that travel in straight paths, requiring a direct path between antennas.

questions.question: What is required for line-of-sight propagation?

options.text: Transmitting and receiving antennas must be aligned and within visible range of each other.
The transmitter must use only omnidirectional antennas to reach many receivers at once.
The receiver must be connected through a physical conductor such as coaxial cable.
Transmitting and receiving antennas must be aligned and within visible range of each other.

questions.explanation: For line-of-sight, antennas must face each other and be placed so the receiver is in view of the transmitter.

questions.question: What limits line-of-sight propagation for ground stations?

options.text: The curvature of the Earth, limiting distance to about 100 km (horizon to horizon).
The curvature of the Earth, limiting distance to about 100 km (horizon to horizon).
The ionosphere, which reflects all line-of-sight signals back down immediately.
The need for a coaxial terminator to prevent signal reflection at the cable end.

questions.explanation: For ground stations, earth curvature blocks straight-line paths, so line-of-sight distance is limited (about 100 km horizon-to-horizon in the course).

questions.question: What are examples of line-of-sight propagation?

options.text: Microwave communication and satellite communication.
AM radio and FM radio broadcasting.
Microwave communication and satellite communication.
Wired Ethernet over twisted pair and optical fiber links.

questions.explanation: The lesson lists microwave and satellite as examples of line-of-sight propagation, where antennas must be aligned with a clear path.

questions.question: What is a directional antenna?

options.text: An antenna that transmits waves in all directions using lower frequencies.
An antenna that transmits signals in a focused beam toward a specific direction.
An antenna that reflects signals off the ionosphere to extend range.
A connector that ensures a cable can be inserted in only one direction.

questions.explanation: Directional antennas concentrate energy into a focused beam and are typically used for point-to-point links at higher frequencies.

questions.question: What are directional antennas typically used for?

options.text: Multicasting where one sender reaches many receivers simultaneously.
Point-to-point communication using high frequencies.
Ground-wave broadcasting where signals spread in all directions along the earth.
Short-range infrared communication inside a closed room via reflection only.

questions.explanation: The course describes directional antennas as focused beams used for point-to-point communication, especially at high frequencies.

questions.question: What is an omnidirectional antenna?

options.text: An antenna that transmits waves in all directions using lower frequencies.
An antenna that uses a parabolic reflector to focus energy at a single point.
An antenna that must be aligned exactly with another antenna to work.
A device that retransmits microwave signals as a repeater over long distances.

questions.explanation: Omnidirectional antennas radiate in all directions, which is useful when many receivers may need to receive the same signal.

questions.question: What advantage do omnidirectional antennas provide?

options.text: Signals can be received by many antennas simultaneously.
Signals can be received by many antennas simultaneously.
They prevent interference by forcing narrow, aligned beams.
They allow high-frequency microwaves to penetrate walls effectively.

questions.explanation: Because they radiate in all directions, omnidirectional antennas support communication where multiple receivers can pick up the signal.

questions.question: How is the electromagnetic spectrum organized?

options.text: It is divided into frequency bands (VLF to EHF) regulated by government authorities.
It is divided into only two ranges: guided and unguided media.
It is divided into OSI layers from Physical to Application.
It is divided into four TCP/IP layers: Application, Transport, Internet, Network Access.

questions.explanation: The lesson explains the electromagnetic spectrum is divided into regulated frequency bands ranging from very low frequency (VLF) to extremely high frequency (EHF).

questions.question: What frequency range defines radio waves?

options.text: Radio waves are between 3 KHz and 1 GHz.
Radio waves are between 1 GHz and 300 GHz.
Radio waves are limited to 30–85 MHz only.
Radio waves are carrier frequencies up to 2 MHz only.

questions.explanation: In the course, radio waves are defined as electromagnetic waves with frequencies from about 3 KHz up to 1 GHz.

questions.question: What frequency range defines microwaves?

options.text: Microwaves are between 1 and 300 GHz.
Microwaves are between 1 and 300 GHz.
Microwaves are between 3 KHz and 1 GHz.
Microwaves are carrier frequencies up to 2 MHz.

questions.explanation: The lesson defines microwaves as electromagnetic waves with frequencies between 1 GHz and 300 GHz.

questions.question: What type of antenna do radio waves use?

options.text: Directional antennas using focused beams and strict alignment.
Omnidirectional antennas.
Parabolic dish antennas only, to concentrate waves at the focus.
Omnidirectional antennas.

questions.explanation: Radio waves are typically transmitted with omnidirectional antennas, spreading energy in all directions.

questions.question: What is a disadvantage of radio waves?

options.text: They are susceptible to interference from other antennas using the same frequency band.
They require a clear line-of-sight path and cannot diffract or spread.
They cannot be received by more than one receiver at a time.
They can only be transmitted through a physical conductor like coaxial cable.

questions.explanation: Because many transmitters can operate in the same band, radio waves are susceptible to interference from other antennas using the same frequencies.

questions.question: Why are radio waves useful for multicasting?

options.text: Because their omnidirectional nature allows one sender to reach many receivers.
Because they are confined to a cable so only intended receivers can access them.
Because their omnidirectional nature allows one sender to reach many receivers.
Because they always use narrow beams and require perfect alignment.

questions.explanation: Radio waves are useful for multicasting because omnidirectional transmission can reach many receivers from a single sender.

questions.question: What are examples of radio wave applications?

options.text: AM and FM radio, television broadcasting, cordless phones, and paging systems.
Microwave tower links and satellite backhaul only.
AM and FM radio, television broadcasting, cordless phones, and paging systems.
Infrared short-range links inside a closed room only.

questions.explanation: The course lists common radio-wave applications such as AM/FM radio, TV broadcasting, cordless phones, and paging systems.

questions.question: What are microwaves?

options.text: Directional electromagnetic waves with frequencies between 1 and 300 GHz.
Low-frequency ground waves with carrier frequencies up to 2 MHz.
Radio waves between 3 KHz and 1 GHz that are typically omnidirectional.
Noncoherent infrared light used for short-range communication.

questions.explanation: Microwaves are defined in the lesson as directional electromagnetic waves in the 1–300 GHz range.

questions.question: How do microwaves propagate?

options.text: By line-of-sight propagation using narrowly focused beams.
By hugging the earth and following its curvature as ground waves.
By line-of-sight propagation using narrowly focused beams.
By reflecting off the ionosphere in sky mode to reach distant receivers.

questions.explanation: Microwaves propagate in line-of-sight mode: focused beams travel in straight lines from antenna to antenna.

questions.question: Why must microwave antennas be aligned?

options.text: Because the transmit and receive stations must be in visible contact.
Because microwaves spread in all directions and need alignment to avoid multicasting.
Because alignment is needed for sky reflection off the ionosphere.
Because microwaves are transmitted through cables and alignment ensures proper connector insertion.

questions.explanation: Microwave links require alignment because communication depends on a direct visible path between transmitting and receiving antennas.

questions.question: What limits microwave communication distance?

options.text: Only the MAC address length used by the devices.
Earth’s curvature and obstacles, often requiring repeaters for long distances.
The ionosphere, which blocks microwaves from traveling in straight lines.
A requirement that microwaves always be omnidirectional and therefore fade quickly.

questions.explanation: The lesson notes that earth curvature and obstacles prevent short towers from communicating over long distances, so repeaters are often needed.

questions.question: Can high-frequency microwaves penetrate walls?

options.text: No, very high-frequency microwaves cannot penetrate walls.
Yes, microwaves penetrate walls better than infrared.
No, very high-frequency microwaves cannot penetrate walls.
Yes, microwaves always pass through walls because they are radio waves.

questions.explanation: The course explicitly states that very high-frequency microwaves cannot penetrate walls.

questions.question: What is the advantage of the microwave frequency band?

options.text: It offers a very wide bandwidth (almost 299 GHz).
It always avoids interference because no other antennas can share the band.
It is limited to carrier frequencies up to 2 MHz, which reduces attenuation.
It guarantees local-only coverage suitable for one locality.

questions.explanation: The microwave band is very wide (nearly 299 GHz in the course), which supports high-capacity transmission.

questions.question: What is a parabolic dish antenna?

options.text: An antenna that focuses waves to a single point (the focus) using a parabolic shape, acting like a funnel.
An omnidirectional antenna that radiates equally in all directions.
A device that reflects radio waves off the ionosphere to extend range.
An antenna that focuses waves to a single point (the focus) using a parabolic shape, acting like a funnel.

questions.explanation: A parabolic dish uses the geometry of a parabola to reflect incoming parallel waves toward a common focus, concentrating the signal.

questions.question: How does a parabolic dish antenna work?

options.text: It broadcasts waves in all directions so many receivers can pick them up.
Incoming parallel waves are reflected toward the focus, concentrating the signal.
It transmits low-frequency ground waves that follow the earth’s curvature.
It modulates noncoherent infrared light for short-range closed-area links.

questions.explanation: Parallel waves arriving at the dish reflect off the curved surface and converge at the focus, which concentrates energy for reception (and similarly focuses outgoing transmission).

questions.question: What is a horn antenna?

options.text: An antenna shaped like a scoop that directs outgoing waves into narrow beams and collects incoming signals.
A keyed connector used to prevent incorrect insertion of twisted-pair cables.
An antenna shaped like a scoop that directs outgoing waves into narrow beams and collects incoming signals.
An antenna that transmits in all directions using lower frequencies.

questions.explanation: The course describes a horn antenna as scoop-shaped: it efficiently directs outgoing waves into narrow beams and collects incoming waves for reception.

questions.question: What type of communication do microwaves support?

options.text: Unicast communication, such as cellular telephones and satellite networks.
Only multicast communication like AM/FM broadcasting.
Only local ground-wave broadcasting for a particular locality.
Only short-range closed-area links using noncoherent infrared light.

questions.explanation: Microwave links are described as directional and line-of-sight, making them well-suited for unicast point-to-point communication such as cellular and satellite networks.

questions.question: What is infrared transmission?

options.text: Transmission using noncoherent infrared light for short-range communication.
Transmission using noncoherent infrared light for short-range communication.
Transmission using focused microwave beams in the 1–300 GHz range.
Transmission using low-frequency ground waves up to 2 MHz.

questions.explanation: Infrared communication uses noncoherent infrared light and is typically intended for short-range links.

questions.question: What condition is required for infrared communication?

options.text: Transceivers must be within line of sight, directly or via reflection.
Transceivers must be connected to a physical conductor to contain the signal.
Signals must reflect off the ionosphere to reach the receiver.
Antennas must be omnidirectional and use lower frequencies for multicasting.

questions.explanation: Infrared transceivers must be in line of sight (directly or by reflection), which constrains how and where infrared links can be used.

questions.question: Can infrared signals penetrate walls?

options.text: Yes, infrared penetrates walls better than microwaves.
No, infrared signals cannot penetrate walls.
No, infrared signals cannot penetrate walls.
Yes, because infrared is a type of radio wave that diffracts through obstacles.

questions.explanation: The lesson states infrared does not penetrate walls, which is why it is commonly used for short-range links in closed areas.

questions.question: Where is infrared transmission typically used?

options.text: Short-range communication in closed areas.
Long-distance cross-country links that require repeaters every 100 km.
Local broadcasting that follows the curvature of the earth for wide-area AM coverage.
Short-range communication in closed areas.

questions.explanation: Infrared is typically used for short-range communication within a closed area, relying on line-of-sight (direct or reflected) paths.

questions.question: What is the key summary of unguided media?

options.text: Unguided media use air to transmit electromagnetic waves via ground, sky, and line-of-sight propagation; microwaves commonly use parabolic dish and horn antennas.
Unguided media require copper conductors and shielding, and they mainly use RJ-45 connectors for transmission.
Unguided media are limited to frequencies up to 2 MHz and therefore cannot support microwave or infrared communication.
Unguided media only support sky propagation, which is always stable and unaffected by weather or time of day.

questions.explanation: The course summarizes unguided media as wireless transmission through air using ground, sky, and line-of-sight propagation, with microwaves using antennas such as parabolic dishes and horns.
